A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
An endomorphism of a ring $R$ is a homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.

A polynomial $f \in R[X]$ with coefficients in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called primitive if the greatest common divisor of all its coefficients is 1, or equivalently, if $
u_p(f) = 0$ for all prime elements $p \in R$.
The unique smallest subfield $P$ of a field $K$, given by the intersection of all subfields in $K$, is referred to as the prime (sub)field in $K$.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is of finite type if there exists an epimorphism $\Phi: A[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] \longrightarrow B$ from a polynomial ring in finitely many variables over $A$ to $B$ that extends $\varphi$. Alternatively, it can be characterized by the existence of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in B$ such that $B=\varphi(A)[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$.

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of the order of an element in a group requires the concept of a group, which is defined using a law of composition.
A ring extension involves subrings and rings, which are defined using laws of composition.
Trivial ideals are defined within the context of a ring, which is defined using a law of composition.
A ring endomorphism is a homomorphism of a ring, which is defined using a law of composition.
A primitive polynomial is defined in terms of a unique factorization domain, which is a type of ring defined using a law of composition.
The prime subfield of a field is defined within the context of a field, which is defined using a law of composition.
A ring homomorphism of finite type is a homomorphism between rings, which are defined using laws of composition.
A finite field is a type of field, which is defined using a law of composition.
A solvable group is a type of group, which is defined using a law of composition.
Disjoint cycles are defined in the context of permutations, which are mappings and thus involve the concept of a codomain.
